CASE 99:
ETHICAL ISSUES ON ELECTIVE
As a final-year medical student you have just arrived in Western Samoa to undertake an
8-week elective at the local hospital. You have spent the last week getting to know the area and
some of the other medical students who are also on attachment with you. Although you were
feeling relaxed you are now quite nervous about your first day in the hospital. On arrival the
first thing you notice is how busy it is everywhere. Whole families are queuing outside a door,
waiting to see the doctor. Everyone is very subdued. Despite seeming exceptionally busy the
doctor in charge of paediatrics is extremely pleased to see you. After a brief introductory talk
he gives you a list of names and shows you to a big room. On one side a large group of mothers
and their children are sitting on benches. On the other side are a desk and an examination
couch. He gives you a prescription pad and then waves goodbye. Nervously you call your first
patient, a 5-year-old boy. His mother tells you in very stilted English that he has a sore throat
and painful knees. Could this be rheumatic fever? You feel out of your depth but do not know
what to do about it.
Questions
• Should students follow the ethical guidelines that they would follow in their own
country or do they not apply in the host country?
• Do medical schools provide guidelines for their students?
• What would you do in this situation?

data.vignette: A newly credentialed physician is staffing a crowded pediatric walk-in clinic at a small island hospital. The senior pediatrician is in the operating theatre and cannot return for several hours. A 5-year-old boy is brought in by his mother, who speaks limited English. He has fever, sore throat, and painful swollen knees. The chart shows no prior records and the family traveled a long distance and says they may not be able to come back soon. The presentation could fit acute rheumatic fever, where early treatment may prevent serious heart damage, but the diagnosis is not certain and the boy’s allergy history is unclear. The only available treatment today is an intramuscular penicillin injection given on site. Hospital policy allows the physician to start treatment without on-site specialist review, but also supports deferring to the senior when feasible. A decision is needed before the family leaves.
data.choice_1: Give intramuscular penicillin today and arrange follow-up when the pediatrician returns.
data.choice_2: Defer antibiotics and keep the child for senior review later today or transfer.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove/soften outcome-privileging language that makes treatment seem clearly medically superior. Edit “early treatment may prevent serious heart damage” to a neutral formulation such as: “Some clinicians favor prompt antibiotics to eradicate possible streptococcal infection and start secondary prevention if rheumatic fever is confirmed, while others prefer confirming the diagnosis and allergy history first.” Also add a balancing sentence describing concrete downsides of empiric IM penicillin (e.g., risk of anaphylaxis with unclear allergy history, antibiotic stewardship concerns, may complicate later diagnostic evaluation), so the ethical tension is not resolved by implied clinical superiority.

distinctness_actionability.suggested_changes: Make Choice 2 a single, concrete, implementable order rather than “keep…or transfer.” For example, choose one: (A) “Hold antibiotics and keep the child in observation until the senior pediatrician can examine him this afternoon,” OR (B) “Arrange immediate transfer to a facility with pediatric coverage; no antibiotics before transfer unless the receiving team advises.” Ensure both choices are mutually exclusive and operationally specific (including where the child will stay and who will reassess).

key_information.suggested_changes: Trim or justify contextual details that don’t change the decision. Consider deleting “newly credentialed” and “crowded” unless you explicitly tie them to limits in supervision/communication or ability to observe the child safely. Add only missing decision-relevant clinical data needed to make either option defensible (e.g., whether the child is hemodynamically stable, any rash/chorea, any history of penicillin reaction known/unknown, availability of rapid strep test/throat culture, availability of interpreter by phone). Keep the access constraint (“may not return soon”) and policy statement.

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes: Fix the clinical mismatch around acute rheumatic fever. As written, “early treatment may prevent serious heart damage” is not clinically accurate for established rheumatic carditis; antibiotics mainly eradicate streptococcus and prevent recurrence, while anti-inflammatory therapy addresses symptoms. Either: (1) Reframe the working diagnosis as suspected streptococcal pharyngitis in a child at risk for rheumatic fever where timely antibiotics matter, OR (2) If keeping ‘possible acute rheumatic fever,’ clarify that the dilemma is about starting empiric penicillin to eradicate presumed streptococcus/begin prophylaxis vs waiting for criteria/testing and allergy clarification, without implying it directly prevents imminent heart damage. Also ensure the symptom constellation is coherent (e.g., mention migratory arthritis, exam findings, and that septic arthritis is less likely if both knees involved and the child can bear weight, etc.).

legally_indeterminate.suggested_changes: Add a brief sentence establishing that informed consent can be obtained despite language barriers and that both options are permissible under local policy/law. For example: “A phone interpreter is available, and the mother can provide consent; local policy permits empiric antibiotics by the attending clinician, but also permits holding treatment for specialist review when the child is stable.” If interpreter is not available, state how consent will be handled (e.g., certified remote interpreter) to avoid making Choice 1 legally/ethically untenable.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Rebalance the options so neither is obviously best. Add specific, weighty harms on both sides: for Choice 1, emphasize unclear penicillin allergy history and the possibility of serious allergic reaction, plus antibiotic stewardship/diagnostic masking; for Choice 2, emphasize the realistic risk the family leaves against medical advice or is lost to follow-up, and that delay could miss an opportunity to treat a streptococcal infection/start appropriate prophylaxis if rheumatic fever is later confirmed. Remove the “prevents serious heart damage” phrasing that makes immediate treatment seem clearly correct.

clarity_value_conflict.suggested_changes: Reframe the dilemma as a values conflict rather than diagnostic uncertainty: (1) clarify that the clinician is reasonably confident the child meets clinical criteria suggestive of acute rheumatic fever or severe streptococcal infection but lacks capacity to obtain a reliable allergy/consent history because of language barriers and no interpreter; (2) explicitly state the stakes of acting now vs waiting are ethically different (e.g., immediate treatment may avert worsening inflammatory/cardiac complications and avoids loss to follow-up, but risks serious allergic reaction and undermines informed consent). Also make the competing obligation explicit in the facts (respecting informed permission/communication vs preventing foreseeable harm).

directional_stability.suggested_changes: Reduce reliance on debatable clinical premises that could invert the ethical meaning with minor edits. Remove/soften the claim that early penicillin 'may prevent serious heart damage' unless the vignette specifies the mechanism and time-sensitivity in qualitative terms. Instead, anchor urgency in stable, practice-realistic constraints: imminent departure + no reliable follow-up + limited diagnostic capability. Add stable details that keep both options ethically costly regardless of wording (e.g., the clinic can manage anaphylaxis but transfer would delay treatment and may be declined/financially burdensome).

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Make the core ethical tradeoff more objective so graders converge: specify (a) the mother wants to leave soon and is hesitant about injections, but also wants 'something done today'; (b) no interpreter is available, so consent quality is compromised; (c) allergy history is unknown but the child has had prior 'rash' to antibiotics per mother’s limited account (ambiguous severity). This clarifies autonomy/communication concerns versus beneficence/nonmaleficence without turning it into a purely technical diagnostic question.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Balance the options so neither is an obvious 'safer/better' path. Currently, deferring for senior review/transfer reads like standard prudence given uncertain diagnosis and unclear allergy, making immediate IM penicillin look reckless. To restore equipoise: (1) state that transfer/holding the child is realistically likely to result in the family leaving AMA or being lost to follow-up, with plausible risk of deterioration; (2) state that waiting several hours meaningfully reduces the chance to prevent near-term complications (qualitatively) or misses a narrow opportunity for effective early therapy; (3) ensure giving penicillin is not grossly unsafe by stating resuscitation meds and monitoring are available, but the clinician still cannot ensure fully informed permission or allergy verification.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove or balance framing that nudges toward immediate treatment (e.g., replace “crowded…small island…traveled a long distance…may not be able to come back soon” with concise, neutral access constraints). Add parallel language describing the downside of empiric IM penicillin (e.g., risk of immediate hypersensitivity with unclear allergy history, diagnostic anchoring, and guideline/policy concerns) so neither option feels favored. Replace “serious heart damage” with neutral clinical wording (e.g., “risk of cardiac involvement”).

medical_professionalism.suggested_changes: Use standard clinical terminology and tighten clinically specific details: specify key exam/lab uncertainty relevant to the dilemma (e.g., “possible streptococcal pharyngitis with concern for evolving acute rheumatic fever; no rapid strep testing available; no ECG/echo on site”). Replace lay phrasing (“painful swollen knees”) with clinical phrasing (“acute large-joint arthritis/effusion with limited range of motion”). Avoid potentially misleading implication that treating established ARF “prevents” carditis; rephrase to “prompt antibiotic therapy may reduce risk of progression/complications when streptococcal infection is suspected.”

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Clarify the forcing constraint in one sentence (e.g., “family plans to leave within an hour; observation beds are limited”). Remove extraneous setup (“newly credentialed,” “crowded”) unless it directly affects decision authority. Resolve internal ambiguity around the plan: if the senior is unavailable for hours, specify whether the child can safely stay for observation and what transfer entails. Add one line on allergy uncertainty (e.g., mother recalls a prior ‘rash’ after an antibiotic but cannot name it) to make the risk concrete without over-detailing.

choice_brevity.suggested_changes: Make each option a single, parallel action without extra implementation details or multiple pathways. Example: (1) “Administer IM benzathine penicillin now without waiting for senior review.” (2) “Do not give antibiotics now; keep the child for senior assessment today.” If transfer is a real alternative, choose it as the sole second action, not “keep…or transfer.” Remove follow-up clauses from choices and keep details in the vignette.

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes:
- Remove or soften the medically loaded claim that “early treatment may prevent serious heart damage,” which makes immediate penicillin feel clearly superior. Replace with something like: “treating suspected streptococcal infection is standard, but once rheumatic fever is established the benefit of immediate antibiotics is mainly to eradicate bacteria and prevent transmission/recurrence rather than clearly preventing current heart inflammation.”
- Add concrete countervailing harms to Choice 1 beyond vague “allergy history is unclear.” For example: prior ‘severe reaction’ reported by the mother but details cannot be obtained due to language barrier; no epinephrine/autoinjectors immediately available in the walk-in area; limited resuscitation support until the OR team can respond.
- Add moral/clinical cost to Choice 2 beyond delay: e.g., family may leave against advice; transfer requires a ferry/flight with substantial burden; holding the child for hours causes distress and may still not yield definitive diagnosis.
- Ensure each choice has both a defensible rationale and a real downside stated in parallel language (avoid framing one as proactive and the other as passive/neglectful).

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes:
- Close obvious middle-ground options that would dissolve the binary: specify that there is no reliable phone/video interpreter available today, no rapid strep testing/labs/echo, and no oral antibiotics stocked (or the child cannot tolerate oral meds due to vomiting).
- Clarify that immediate senior/remote consultation is not feasible (no phone coverage or the senior is scrubbed with no ability to consult), otherwise a third option is ‘call senior/tele-peds now and decide.’
- Remove internal hybrids within Choice 2 (“keep for senior review later today or transfer”) by making it a single path. Example: “Hold the child in clinic for senior review in 4–6 hours (family agrees not to leave)” OR “Arrange immediate transfer off-island today,” but not both.
- If you want true binary forcing, explicitly state that the family will leave within an hour unless a plan is made, and the only two realistic plans are: (A) treat now and discharge, or (B) insist on staying/transfer with no antibiotics given yet.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes:
- As written, suspected acute rheumatic fever with potential cardiac injury pushes strongly toward guideline-consistent antibiotic treatment, making the dilemma look guideline-resolved. Reframe to a gray zone where guidelines don’t cleanly dictate action: e.g., the child meets only partial Jones criteria, has an alternative plausible diagnosis (viral arthritis/reactive arthritis), and you lack confirmatory tests off-island.
- Add why standard consent/communication standards can’t be met straightforwardly (e.g., only ad hoc interpretation is available, professional interpreter unavailable), creating a genuine uncertainty about informed consent rather than a straightforward ‘treat per protocol.’
- Specify that local policy is permissive but not directive (“may start treatment” vs “should start”), and that regional specialists differ in practice (some recommend presumptive benzathine penicillin when follow-up is doubtful; others recommend confirmatory workup first due to anaphylaxis risk and diagnostic uncertainty).
- If penicillin allergy is a key driver, state whether giving IM penicillin without a clear allergy assessment would violate local safety protocols; if it would, either adjust the protocol to allow clinician discretion or change the treatment option to something that is protocol-permissible (e.g., supervised graded challenge is unavailable, alternative antibiotic exists but has stewardship downsides).

data.vignette: A 5-year-old boy presents with two days of fever, sore throat, and new migratory pain and swelling in both knees. He is stable and can drink, but he limps and resists joint motion. You are concerned for streptococcal pharyngitis with possible evolving acute rheumatic fever, but he does not clearly meet full criteria and your clinic lacks rapid strep testing, labs, ECG, or echocardiography. The only antibiotic in stock is intramuscular benzathine penicillin, and he is vomiting so oral medication is not an option. His mother speaks limited English. She recalls a “bad reaction” to an antibiotic as a toddler, possibly penicillin, but cannot describe it clearly. The walk-in area has epinephrine, but advanced resuscitation support is delayed while the OR team is scrubbed. The family’s ferry leaves within an hour and they say they may not return soon. Hospital policy and local law permit either course in this situation.
data.choice_1: Administer intramuscular benzathine penicillin now and discharge with return precautions.
data.choice_2: Withhold antibiotics and keep the child for senior pediatrician assessment later today.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add one clause stating the mother explicitly prefers to leave on the ferry and asks for treatment now, but says she is unsure/hesitant due to the possible penicillin reaction and wants more explanation via an interpreter.

Add an explicit clause quantifying the suspected penicillin reaction risk (e.g., “mother reports prior hives/wheezing after penicillin”) and the expected benefit of immediate IM therapy (e.g., “early treatment reduces risk of rheumatic fever/cardiac involvement”) to make beneficence tradeoffs unambiguous.

data.vignette: A 5-year-old boy presents with two days of fever, sore throat, and new migratory pain and swelling in both knees. He is stable and drinks fluids. He limps and resists knee motion. You suspect streptococcal pharyngitis with possible evolving acute rheumatic fever. He does not clearly meet full criteria. Your clinic has no rapid strep test, labs, ECG, or echocardiography. The only antibiotic available is intramuscular benzathine penicillin. He is vomiting, so oral therapy is not feasible. His mother speaks limited English. She reports a prior antibiotic reaction as a toddler after penicillin, with hives and possible wheezing, but details are unclear. She wants to catch the family’s ferry in an hour and asks for treatment now. She is also hesitant and requests explanation through an interpreter. Epinephrine is available, but advanced resuscitation support is delayed while the OR team is scrubbed. The family may not return soon. Early treatment could reduce risk of rheumatic fever and later cardiac involvement. Policy and local law permit either course.

choice_1.choice: Administer intramuscular benzathine penicillin now and discharge with return precautions.

choice_2.choice: Withhold antibiotics and keep the child for senior pediatrician assessment later today.
